video_title: Bio-Intelligence: Generative Molecules to Autonomous Care - SuperAI Singapore 2025
description:
Learn more about SuperAI: superai.com
Follow us on X: x.com/superai_conf

Panel: Bio-Intelligence: Generative Molecules to Autonomous Care

Speakers:
Munjal Shah, Co-Founder and CEO @ Hippocratic AI
Alex Aliper, Co-Founder and President @ Insilico Medicine
Mahyar Salek, CTO @ Deepcell

Moderator:
Ali Tamaseb, General Partner @ DCVC

Stage: io.net Main Stage
#superai #biotech #ai #medtech #healthcare 

Recorded on 18 June 2025

transcript.aggregated_text: bio intelligence applications of general generative AI in healthcare and biotech i'm going to be your moderator today my name is Alita Masab i'm a general partner at DCVC dcvc is a Silicon Valley based venture capital firm we invested about $4 billion at the intersection of AI and deep tech that includes lots of companies in the healthcare biotech and diagnostic space i'm also author of Superfounders a book about startup founders and what makes them successful but today it's all about these three gentlemen um we will talk about from basically hype to reality is this the time where AI has actually been deployed in healthcare biotech pharma and diagnostics so I will go through the panel uh Munjaw is co-founder and CEO of Hypocratic AI they use generative AI for healthcare delivery alex of Incilico Medicine they use generative AI to design new molecules and biologics and Mahiar co-founder and CTO of Deep Cell and the applications of tools AI in tools and cell diagnostics um so with that I think each each everyone in the panel would love for you to go a couple minutes talk about the genesis of your company what the company does and where AI comes into play and then we'll get into the meat of the questions uh so I'm on anjal sha um uh hypocratic AI we started the company actually in like March of 23 so we saw chat GPT and honestly um as a uh person who had studied AI and built two AI companies and then built a healthcare company I said oh wow we finally have AI that works and so it's time to start a company around this and so uh we started Hypocratic what we do is we provide healthcare AI agents that operate uh predominantly within the scope of nursing um reaching out to patients talking to them on the phone doing care activities um and we sell them to health systems to payers which are insurance companies in the US and to pharma and so uh that's the company we're based in uh Silicon Valley we've raised about $270 million in the last 24 months alex Aliper president of Filico we we're a global biotechnology company we discover new drugs new medicines against agent related disorders cancer fibrosis metabolism disorders and we developed a platform geni platform that helps us discover drugs more efficiently and faster so currently traditional pharma spends billions and over decades to get a single molecule in the market we want to change that paradigm because we need more medicines uh fast and uh we have been able to demonstrate that we can shorten the time frame for drug discovery three times so three-fold instead of 5 years we're doing it in 18 months and we do we're doing it at fraction of the cost so currently we have 30 drug discovery uh programs uh 10 of them are in clinic phase one phase two and our recent phase two study in lung fibrosis have just been published in nature medicine where we showed efficacy in patients with IPF lung fibrosis and it's the first case where AI discovered molecule has shown efficacy in real human patients so yeah that's our business model platform and pipeline and I'm Salg I'm co-founder and CTO of company called Deep Cell um if you think about well we're an iteration over microscope if you think about microscope as an eye we are an eye that is empowered by brain tells tells us like what you see and an arm that tells you like well if you see something that's interesting you could actually take it out so you could actuate on that so that's a deep cell product we empower uh bioharma companies understand like how drugs affect their um the underlying cell samples we empower diagnostic applications clinical applications and we've recently commercialized globally perfect so first question what I want to understand is what did you have to invent offtheshelf that was that was basically not off the shelf right what did you have to build yourselves in this time of AI that there's lots of companies with lots of products of AI out there that already exists yeah you know the um the primary challenge of what we're building is one it has to be extremely safe like even a nurse talking to a patient on the phone can kill them if they tell them to take ibuprofen and they have chronic kidney disease stage three or four and we couldn't have the AI mostly get that right it has to never recommend ibuprofen to a CKD 34 patient 100% of the time um the second issue we had was we realized that voice was the only way to truly canote you care the empathy and emotion you can feel in voice is quite different in fact part of our thesis was that there's a voice renaissance coming that it's such a natural emotional way to communicate with patients that you're that that's how we're going to do it but you have a very small latency budget when you talk about voice in fact you look at all the models that have been improving lately um the you know from deepseek onward to the latest uh Gemini 2.5 they've done it by increasing latency in fact so much so you can't use them for voice like you can you have to get an answer in 500 milliseconds for voice so we had to work on a whole host of new technologies to allow you to make a smart safe AI that answers in less than 500 milliseconds from the LLM standpoint and we did that with a unique architecture so we came out with a new unique architecture we call the constellation model where it's 22 models working together we came out with uh a new way to actually do inference that speeds up inference time of especially large dense models to ensure we can meet that 500 millisecond limit including a very novel thing we call vertical quantization um and on top of all that we had to come up with a clinical validation system on the back end because nobody tests the output of LLM they say oh my LM safe this is what I trained it on i'm like how do you know have you seen PubMed GPT trained only on PubMed highquality content still make stuff up all the time and so we actually are the only ones where we hired 6,000 nurses to do uh 300,000 test calls to the AI and mark every last error and we only shipped it when it was as safe as a human clinician and so there was a lot of pieces that we had to kind of figure out to do this perfect Alex well we started back in 2014 and it was a cusp of a like generative AI revolution right so Ian Goodfellow published the uh GAN paper and we immediately started working on applying generative algorithms to discovering like new drugs generating small molecules and at that time 2015 2016 nobody like even knew what generative AI was so we had to like pioneer this field so first peer-reviewed paper on generative chemistry we published it in 2016 where we generated uh drugs molecules against cancer from scratch um using generated fedricerial autoenccoders and um since then we kind of pitched this to big pharma and at first people were aggressively skeptical saying it won't work but then later on when we showed validation and uh some results we kind of were convinced and now every single university like even lazy professor has a like AI drug discovery uh program so another challenge what we had to overcome so in our space it's not ch you have no idea if a molecule if a model generated would work until you actually physically make it and test it so we had to spend a lot of time and resources to go in the lab to experimentally validate the output of each single model and every validated model we included uh the the model into the platform and build a platform uh which is currently being used by half of the top 20 big pharma companies there you are yeah so what did we innovate on so we are at this very intersection of AI hardware and biology each of them very hard when you combine them together extremely hard um actually we hired from autonomous driving uh engineers the reason is that so so remember so we image these cells they're flowing very fast and based on the image we decide where they should go so imagine it's almost like a car driving in this like micro road where you see all these particles and you have to decide okay so this go that way this go this way so it's really an autonomous driving uh problem at the micro scale so we had to do a lot of distribution of computation across different layers of you know GPU FPGA etc and then each of those particles are these like tiny fragile viable cells that if if you mishandle you lose the biology so there there was a lot of innovation at the intersection of all three that we had to overcome interesting seems to me from kind of Mjal and Yar the the main thing that's not off the shelf is like if you need the accuracy and you need the speed you need to innovate yourself you can't just buy it off the shelf something that has lower the the latency that you require and the you know efficacy that you require um next question about regulation we want to talk about FDA and CMS and all the you know bodies that regulate healthcare and biotech have they really kept up with the pace of innovation are they helping are they hurting maybe we start from that side yeah so historically regulatory bodies have been behind um uh the pace of AI well I guess that's for everybody right you know we're all all catching up with AI but regulatory is especially slow uh with that said I mean there has been some positive movements over even over the last few months uh you know we saw FDA they uh published this uh uh PCC uh PCCP guideline January of um 2015 2025 where you know we and and there is this you know uh in the US there is this bill in the Senate that is uh about the um health tech which is as recent as April so there is a lot of movement but it's still historically uh the pace of AI is faster than anything else that you know is happening around yeah I would say for FDA I think what they're doing this year is pretty remarkable and pro- innovation right on top of uh like recent uh announcements we've also deploying like Genai platform across the organization every organization due to be completed by the end of this month i think that was announced um and that would allow importantly to reduce review cycles on drug discovery drug development programs so typically the bottleneck right now with the FDA is the review time like process right how how long does it take the FDA experts to review an application to review a clinical trial results and provide guidance on what to do next to a pharma company so this will have a chance of uh improving and accelerating the review cycle so we'll have the rap more rapid um turnaround process and more rapid u progression of clinical trials yeah you know one of the reasons we picked um our agents focus to not be a doctor and to not diagnose is that keeps you out of the clinical decision support requirement within the FDA so that was one thing but second even if it had if it hadn't you know the FDA today is um you know uh having met with uh Dr draws on the CMS side but as well as um RFK they're very forwardleaning on AI both of them i mean extremely forwardleaning so I think in the US at least there's a very pro- AI administration um that's making it easier and paving the way for a lot of um uh easier time but I I think on the flip side in Europe the EU AI act is just a total nightmare like here's Europe thinking we're going to regulate first before we even understand what the thing is and I I'll give you an example so if we add one feature to our AI agent it's actually going to make it the highest risk within the uh EU AI act and that feature is that it senses the emotion of a patient reacts so you don't want my nurse to say you know uh my AI agent to say um to be able to tell the difference between you saying "My back hurts and my back hurts." Cuz those are very different things and the agent should absolutely notice the difference but if I make it do that it's now the highest risk requires the highest approval and I think they just weren't thinking and understanding the issue when they made these regulations and oh by the way the fine is 7% of worldwide revenues and it's written so vaguely you're almost 100% going to trip it and so you look at all these things and you're like you know so I've had so many clients come to me they're like can you please deploy your product in Europe i'm like no I'm absolutely not going to deploy it in Europe when you guys change this law give me a call something that I I was reading about recently about FDA and about them kind of being pro pro AI there's hundreds of thousands of submissions to to the documents that comes in so they are starting to kind of apply AI on FDA's term to actually be able to parse through all these documentations and submissions that's encouraging yeah it is i think it's pretty good um now we want to talk about AI and a little bit of the highend reality right what do we think AI can actually change in healthcare in biotech in diagnostics in in your basically area of expertise and then what do you think it can probably never touch or not touch in the next 1015 years so I know this is going to be uh an interesting comment although not surprising I guess i think generative AI in at least the use cases we're looking at is probably underhyped and the reason I say that is when you look at nursing in the US there's a huge shortage and so you could say I'm going to come in we're going to help solve some of that shortage but the really big idea is not just doing things you do today right when the cost of something drops 10x or 100x you do novel things you never did before so for example in the next heat wave in the US we're going to be reaching out to every single one of these 200,000 patients that this one health plan has identified that are at risk we're going to call them we're going to do a heat stroke triage we're going to call an Uber then and get them to a cooling center if they're having issues we're going to do that at the hottest two hours of the day every single day of the heat wave now you could never do that with humans you literally couldn't you'd have to find 50,000 nurses to call people at the hottest two to call 200,000 people at the hottest two hours of the day with what 5 days 10 days advanced notice of a coming heatwave and it would cost you 2 million of 5 million to 20 million to do that every single day well are you really going to save that much money on ER admits probably not but with AI you can do it for $200,000 a day in fact in the next generation Nvidia chip comes out it'll maybe be as low as $50,000 a day and that's at our retail price not even at like the true COGS underneath it and so when you look at all that you're like my god there's a level of outreach and care we can deliver that's amazing now on the what shouldn't you do i don't think we're going to get an AI doctor anytime soon i think it's too hard i think you're going to kill somebody um even um there's other areas that I don't think are safe to do it we do not let our agents do mental health because it's quite ambiguous you know if I do a check-in call for a congestive heart failure patient I know the questions I got to do right so you have both like the shield and the sword uh to tackle that challenge so AI can already like provably de demonstrabably uh accelerate that process now in terms of what AI cannot do I agree ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure the problem is it's actually the reverse a pound of prevention is worth an ounce of cure because the cost of intervening has been so high and such short supply and now I think for the first time in human history we have this ability to check in with every patient every day if we want you know my my mother got was recently diagnosed with congestive heart failure and she ended up going to the hospital with a blood pressure of 230 and when we got there we were like "Huh how did this all of a sudden happen?" And her doctor looked up in her medical record and was like "Oh actually your mom's been on a blood pressure lowering medicine for the last 5 years." I'm like "What?" Cuz when I talked to her she was like "Oh I saw the doctor he said "For my age I'm the healthiest woman he knows." I mean she just totally just you know told her family that she was totally fine when in fact she had this and she didn't take it and she didn't get refills and sure enough 5 years later she ended up with mild CHF and I'm like God I wish the doctor had called her cuz he's the only one that knew because of US HIPPA laws if she doesn't tell us we don't have any other way to know uh and as a child you feel so awful you're like "My mom was there for me and I can't be there for her what should I have done i should have checked." Like you know you feel so guilty but really the doctor could have called her you could have said "Hey you didn't get your refill ma'am are you still taking the blood pressure you know it's really important that you take you know can you take your blood pressure from me right now and they could have done that every single week for the last 5 years and we might have avoided this that's the power of what this abundance is going to deliver for us and I think all of human history we've been thinking about healthcare has been premised on scarcity like I think you go 4,000 years ago to ancient Greece we did not have enough healthcare workers so even the word triage assumed scarcity and I think this shift to abundance is a massive paradigm shift that honestly we've never done before in healthcare well in terms of productivity on our side you know the program I mentioned lung fibrosis program to get from zero to preclinical candidate to actual molecule it took us costwise around two
